Title: Blue-banded Bee
Description: Amegilla cingulata

An important bee in Australia which is said to contribute very significantly towards pollination of crop plants as well as natives.

They are capable of stinging but are not aggressive to humans.

They are solitary insects which make their burrow in clay, sandstone or even the mortar in brickwork.

They are found throughout Australia except for Tasmania.  It is prey to a number of frogs, birds and the cane toad.  Its nests are parasited by the Neon Cuckoo Bee which has similar colouring to mimic its target species.

DSC08075

Title: Female Cane toad (Scientific name: Rhinella marina)

Title: Merten's Water Monitor
Description: A species of lizard found in Northern Australia which have become threatened due to spread of Cane Toads which they eat and ingest the poison. Found in waterways.

Title: Cane toad (Rhinella marina)
Description: Cane toads are native to South and Central America and were originally introduced into Australia in 1935 to control destructive beetles in the sugarcane crops of Queensland, with disastrous results. These hardy, poisonous and voracious predators soon became a pest in the northern regions of Australia, competing with native species (and especially native predators, as it is the case in Kakadu National Park).

Mary River - Northern Territory, Australia.

Title: olive longsnouted treefrog-scinax elaeochroa
Description: December 23rd was a day of discovery for everyone at what we called our Christmas house.  I slept in after being up late the night before and up super early the last couple of days.  By the time I had gotten up everyone was excited with all the the beautiful wonderful things they were finding around our house.  The beach was amazing and so was the sunrise my wife tells me.  My oldest daughter had fun picking all kinds of tropical fruit from the many fruit trees on the 5 acre property.  My younger daughters had fun at the beach and watching the toucans and scarlet macaws that had already been visiting that morning.  And my son had already found 3 types of lizards in the yard, black spiny tailed iguanas, whiptails and some kind of anole and he was having fun chasing them around.  

I had volunteered to go to town on the super bumpy pothole dirt road to get our groceries for the next several days.  I also planned to meet a guy who was a retired naturalist and who had a ecotourism company but unfortunately I found out he was actually very sick.  Like alarmingly coughing sick.  It turned out he was a bad smoker and was having major lung issues and would not be able to guide me on a hike like I had hoped.  I did get some information on some other guides from him and did have a nice conversation with him about the wildlife of the area but was very sad about his health and disappointed that we wouldn't be able to go on a hike together.    

My daughter who was the main cook for our family on this trip had given me a very long grocery list in multiple text messages that was not in the order I would have put it in and which I had to spend a lot of time going through to find everything.  Not to mention the grocery stores there put things in strange places.  In hindsight I should have taken 5 minutes to cut and paste it into a proper notepad document and order it efficiently.   I literally spent 3 hours at the grocery store and mostly missed out on doing anything that day.  

By the time I was done with my errands in Puerto Jimenez it was already getting dark and starting to rain.  On the way back to the house I saw some of what looked like barn owls but I didn't have my camera with me.  I also saw some very large frogs hopping across the road and though of catching one for my son to see but focused instead on getting home so we could go explore.  

After unpacking the groceries and eating dinner the rain had started to subside a little and I was ready to get out and explore.  My wife and I had to convince my son that it would be more fun for us to go on a night hike than it would be to stay there and just chase the house geckos all over the house walls. We finally left the house much later than I would have hoped for.  

I decided to drive back to that river I hadn't wanted to cross the night before and hike a trail I saw that looked like it followed the river for a ways.
After we got there, got our gear on and started down the trail a truck drove up and stopped by our vehicle. We weren't too far down the trail so I went back to see what the person wanted or at least let them know I was watching them. The truck said Osa Conservation so I figured they must work for one of the local land trusts / ecolodges and decided to try and talk to him.  Unfortunately the guy only spoke spanish and I speak very little spanish so we couldn't communicate very well. I knew he was telling me that trail was private even though it was not marked private and I tried to ask him where we could hike and he seemed to indicate on the other side of the river I didn't want to cross in the dark. 

Back up the road there was a sign for a bird sanctuary that I had also thought of trying to do a night hike at so I drove back there and some dogs were out barking. The owner of the house came out and i asked him if this was the bird sanctuary pointing to the sign and he said in Spanish that no it was like 3km down the road. I really didn't want to cross that wide river in the dark so I decided to ask him if I could hike around on his property to look for snakes. He was a little surprised I wanted to look for snakes especially with my 6 year old son but was also very friendly and let me park on his property since its not a good idea to park on the roadside at night. I even tried to pay him for letting me park and hike there but he would not accept my money. He merely replied No, Mucho Gusto and Pura Vida. That man exemplified the best of the humans in Costa Rica. 

Unfortunately aside from a couple of little frogs that we had already seen on this trip and spiders we didn't find anything. I did find an interesting camera trap aimed at where something might cross a log over a stream. I wondered if that trap sometimes caught Jaguars or cougars crossing there. After that hike I thought of maybe stopping at the place we had gone the night before but for some reason didn't feel like it and we just drove back to our rental. When we got back I decided we should look around the 5 acres of fruit trees and flowering trees on the rental property to see what we could see. Unfortunately we only found a cane toad and this cute treefrog right outside the house. We explored farther into the yard but didn't find anything else.

I somehow only took like 10 photos that whole day and had to go back through my cameras memory cards twice just to verify I didn't somehow lose any.  Its sad that I don't remember a lot about that day. But the highlight was definitely meeting that nice Costa Rican living in the jungle with his dogs who wouldn't even accept any money from me and was happy to let us explore his property in  the dark.

Title: Portrait: Cane Toad
Description: An Australian Cane Toad (Rhinella marina) from Mt Isa in north-western Queensland. An attractive species deliberately introduced into Australia and responsible for enormous ecological damage. 

Canon EOS 5D Mark IV coupled to an EF Mount Laowa 100/2.8 2:1 macro apo lens. Lit with a diffused, dual flash rig.

Title: 0867 Water Monitor
Description: This juvenile Merten's Water Monitor (?) wasn't disturbed by our presence as we walked back out of the paperbark swamp.  It was covered in just as many  mosquitos as we were. Really pleased to see this lizard as the populations of many species that eat amphibians were badly affected by the arrival of the toxic cane toads.  Seven Spirit Bay, Coburg Peninsula, Northern Territory.

account: Frederick County Forest Conservancy District Board (188126226@N02)
description: Title: 3. Chinese chestnut (Castanea mollissima), Non-native Description: Chestnuts roasting on an open fire…This lovely holiday tune was written in 1945, a time when you could still find a few American chestnut trees and the fall harvest of the tasty nuts were available to give rise to festivals and inspire songs and literary references. However, when we brought Japanese chestnut trees here around the turn of the last century, we accidentally brought a little hitchhiker here as well, a pathogenic fungus that would, in less than 50 years, wipe out pretty much every single American chestnut on the continent, about four billion trees. This is an excellent example of how the very human desire to have it all has often causes havoc in our natural ecosystems. Now, we have Japanese honeysuckle, kudzu, Asian bittersweet, zebra mussels, marmorated stinkbugs, emerald ash borer and cane toads to deal with, causing untold millions of dollars to be spent on control of these species that arrive here with no diseases, predators or other natural controls. We’ve thankfully learned a lot since those days, but must be constantly vigilant about bringing species to new locations where they could quickly become a serious problem. Chinese chestnut trees have been exposed to the chestnut blight fungus for a very long time and thus have been able to evolve defenses against it so they thrive here in the United States. Scientists are working on a hybrid of Chinese chestnut and American chestnut trees that can withstand the blight and integrate into our forest ecosystems, providing all the resources our wildlife used to enjoy. These three lovely Hood campus trees have been producing a bountiful harvest for many years to the delight of the local wildlife--fat squirrels that can be seen eating and hiding the plump, shiny nuts in September. First, they have to wait until the spiny husk splits open and drops the seeds because that husk is just rude. In-the-know humans can share in this bounty, too. Just score the nuts and pop them into the oven or, roast in a pie pan over an open fire. Make sure you sing when you do, to get the full experience! Photo 1 of 3 Go to the next tree in the Hood College tree walk. This tree can be found at coordinates: 39.42072, -77.41783 and on the map of all trees on the Hood Tree Walk Credit: frederick.forestryboard.org - Bethany Dell'Agnello

Title: Cane toad
Description: It is raining cats and dogs today and probably the next few days too due to hurricane Eta for the coast of Nicaragua. It brings lots of rain and floodings in Central America. A night shot with only a flashlight from the largest toad in Costa Rica, about 20cms. Have a nice day and stay safe my friends, the situation is improving a little bit here but we need to wait more in my opinion.
Please click for the larger image to see all details! Thank you for all the views, comments and fav. It is very much appreciated, though the written comments are the most interesting! Title: BIRDS UK
Description: Photograph above:
Whilst waiting to photograph something VERY different this young chap turned up and sat on a railing and wanted to be snapped, glad he joined me!

Photograph Copyright: Digital Expression UK (2020)

OVERVIEW
Corvus is a widely distributed genus of medium-sized to large birds in the family Corvidae. The genus includes species commonly known as crows, ravens and rooks; there is no consistent distinction between "crows" and "ravens", and these appellations have been assigned to different species chiefly on the basis of their size, crows generally being smaller than ravens.

The 45 or so members of this genus occur on all temperate continents except South America, and several islands. The crow genus makes up a third of the species in the family Corvidae. The members appear to have evolved in Asia from the corvid stock, which had evolved in Australia. The collective name for a group of crows is a "flock" or a "murder". The genus name is Latin for "raven".

Recent research has found some crow species capable of not only tool use, but also tool construction. Crows are now considered to be among the world's most intelligent animals with an encephalization quotient equal to that of many non-human primates.

Description
Medium-large species are ascribed to the genus, ranging from 34 cm of some small Mexican species to 60–70 cm of the large common raven and thick-billed raven, which together with the lyrebird represent the larger passerines.

These are birds with a robust and slender appearance, equipped with a small rounded head with a strong conical beak, elongated and pointed, with a slightly curved end towards the bottom: the legs are strong and the tail is short and wedge-shaped .

The coloration of the livery is dominated by shades of black, with some species having plumage with metallic iridescences and others that have white or grey areas on the neck or torso: Australian species have light eyes, while generally the irises are dark.

Evolutionary history and systematics
The members of the genus Corvus are believed to have evolved in Central Asia and radiated out from there into North America, Africa, Europe, and Australia.

The latest evidence regarding the evolution indicates descent within the Australasian family Corvidae. However, the branch that would produce the modern groups such as jays, magpies, and large, predominantly black Corvus species had left Australasia and were concentrated in Asia by the time the Corvus species evolved.

The genus was originally described by Carl Linnaeus in his 1758 10th edition of Systema Naturae. The name is derived from the Latin corvus meaning "raven".

The type species is the common raven (Corvus corax); others named in the same work include the carrion crow (C. corone), the hooded crow (C. cornix), the rook (C. frugilegus), and two species which have since been moved to other genera, the western jackdaw (now Coloeus monedula) and the Eurasian magpie (now Pica pica). At least 42 extant species are now considered to be members of Corvus, and at least 14 extinct species have been described.

The fossil record of crows is rather dense in Europe, but the relationships among most prehistoric species are not clear. Corvids are found in major cities across the world, and a major increase in the number of crows in urban settings has occurred since the 1900s. Historical records suggest that the population of American crows found in North America has been growing steadily since the introduction of European colonization, and spread east to west with the opening of the frontier. Crows were uncommon in the Pacific Northwest in the 1900s, except in riparian habitats. Populations in the west increased substantially from the late 1800s to the mid-1900s. Crows and ravens spread along with agriculture and urbanization into the western part of North America.

Behaviour
Crows gather in large communal roosts numbering between 200 and tens of thousands of individuals during nonbreeding months, particularly in the winter. These gatherings tend to happen near large food sources such as garbage dumps and shopping centres. 

Play
Countless incidents are recorded of corvids at play. Many behaviourists see play as an essential quality in intelligent animals.

Calls
Crows and the other members of the genus make a wide variety of calls or vocalisations. Crows have also been observed to respond to calls of other species; presumably, this behaviour is learned because it varies regionally. Crows' vocalizations are complex and poorly understood. Some of the many vocalizations that crows make are a "koww", usually echoed back and forth between birds, a series of "kowws" in discrete units, a long caw followed by a series of short caws (usually made when a bird takes off from a perch), an echo-like "eh-aw" sound, and more. These vocalisations vary by species, and within each species they vary regionally. In many species, the pattern and number of the numerous vocalizations have been observed to change in response to events in the surroundings (e.g. arrival or departure of crows).

Intelligence
As a group, crows show remarkable examples of intelligence. Natural history books from the 18th century recount an often-repeated, but unproven anecdote of "counting crows" — specifically a crow whose ability to count to five (or four in some versions) is established through a logic trap set by a farmer. Crows and ravens often score very highly on intelligence tests. Certain species top the avian IQ scale. Wild hooded crows in Israel have learned to use bread crumbs for bait-fishing. Crows engage in a kind of mid-air jousting, or air-"chicken" to establish pecking order. They have been found to engage in activities such as sports, tool use, the ability to hide and store food across seasons, episodic-like memory, and the ability to use individual experience in predicting the behaviour of proximal conspecifics.

One species, the New Caledonian crow, has also been intensively studied recently because of its ability to manufacture and use tools in the day-to-day search for food. On 5 October 2007, researchers from the University of Oxford presented data acquired by mounting tiny video cameras on the tails of New Caledonian crows. They pluck, smooth, and bend twigs and grass stems to procure a variety of foodstuffs. Crows in Queensland have learned how to eat the toxic cane toad by flipping the cane toad on its back and violently stabbing the throat where the skin is thinner, allowing the crow to access the nontoxic innards; their long beaks ensure that all of the innards can be removed.

The western jackdaw and the Eurasian magpie have been found to have a nidopallium about the same relative size as the functionally equivalent neocortex in chimpanzees and humans, and significantly larger than is found in the gibbons.

Crows have demonstrated the ability to distinguish individual humans by recognizing facial features. Evidence also suggests they are one of the few nonhuman animals, along with insects like bees or ants, capable of displacement (communication about things that are not immediately present, spatially or temporally). Ravens have been observed to recruit other ravens to large feeding sites, such as to the carcass of an animal.

Title: Trinidad - Carnival in 1967
Description: <u>The Postcard</u>

A postally unused postcard published in 1967 by Y. de Lima & Co. Ltd. of Trinidad & Tobago, W.I. The card was printed in the USA by Dexter Press Inc. of West Nyack, New York.

On the divided back of the card the publishers state:

'Carnival in Trinidad, W.I.
The World's Greatest Show'.

<u>Trinidad</u>

Trinidad is the larger and more populous of the two islands of Trinidad and Tobago. The island lies 11 km (6.8 mi) off the north-eastern coast of Venezuela, and sits on the continental shelf of South America. 

It is often referred to as the southernmost island in the Caribbean. With an area of 5,131 km2 (1,981 sq mi), it is also the fifth largest in the West Indies.

<u>Trinidad's Name</u>

Caribs and Arawaks lived in Trinidad long before Christopher Columbus encountered the islands during his third voyage on the 31st. July 1498. 

The original name for the island in the Arawaks' language was Iëre which meant 'Land of the Hummingbird'. Christopher Columbus re-named it La Isla de la Trinidad ('The Island of the Trinity'), fulfilling a vow he had made before setting out on his third voyage. This has since been shortened to Trinidad.

<u>History of Trinidad</u>

The island remained Spanish until 1797, but it was largely settled by French colonists from the French Caribbean, especially Martinique. In 1889 the two islands became a single British Crown colony. Trinidad and Tobago obtained self-governance in 1958, and independence from the United Kingdom in 1962.

<u>Geography of Trinidad</u>

Major landforms include the hills of the Northern, Central and Southern Ranges (Dinah ranges), the Caroni, Nariva and Oropouche Swamps, and the Caroni and Naparima Plains. 

Major river systems include the Caroni, North and South Oropouche and Ortoire Rivers. There are many other natural landforms such as beaches and waterfalls. 

Trinidad has two seasons per the calendar year: the rainy season and the dry season.

<u>Trinidad's Culture</u>

There are multiple festivals featuring the music of the Caribbean and the steelpan, which originated in Trinidad and is the country's national instrument. 

These festivals include the world-renowned Carnival, J'Ouvert, and Panorama, the national steel pan competition. 

Trinidad also has many public holidays, such as Indian Arrival Day, Emancipation Day, Independence Day, Republic Day, Labour Day, Boxing Day, New Year's Day, Diwali, Phagwa, Eid al-Fitr, Corpus Christi, Good Friday, Easter, Easter Monday, Christmas, and Spiritual Baptist/Shouter Liberation Day. 

Places of cultural significance include Mount Saint Benedict and the Temple in the Sea.

<u>Zoology of Trinidad</u>

The island of Trinidad has a rich biodiversity. The fauna is overwhelmingly of South American origin. There are about 100 species of mammals including the Guyanese red howler monkey, the collared peccary, the red brocket deer, the ocelot and about 70 species of bats. 

There are over 400 species of birds including the endemic Trinidad piping-guan. Reptiles are well represented, with about 92 recorded species, including the largest species of snake in the world, the green anaconda, the spectacled caiman, and one of the largest lizards in the Americas, the green iguana. 

The largest of turtles (the leatherback turtle) nests on Trinidad's eastern and northern beaches. There are 37 recorded frog species, including the tiny El Tucuche golden tree frog, and the more widespread huge cane toad. 

About 43 species of freshwater fish are known in Trinidad, including the well known guppy. It is estimated that there are at least 80,000 arthropods, and at least 600 species of butterfly. Arthropods include centipedes, insects, spiders and crustaceans.

Title: Blue Banded Bee (Amegilla cingulata) Description: Blue Banded Bee (Amegilla cingulata) en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amegilla_cingulata Amegilla cingulata, commonly known as the blue-banded bee, is an Australian native bee that occurs in many other regions. Currently, several scientific organizations are conducting research on how the blue-banded bee benefits agriculture through its distinctive "buzz pollination". These bees are very important for the production of food and contribute to at least 30% of crops in Australia. A. cingulata builds a solitary nest, but often close to other conspecifics. Blue-banded bees tend to nest in burrows in dried-up river banks, old clay homes, and mortar between bricks, but may also burrow in soft sandstone, and areas of this type of rock can become riddled with bee tunnels.Cells, at the end of tunnels, contain an egg with a pollen/nectar mixture for the larval food.A. cingulata is preyed upon by many animals, including the cane toad, frogs, and birds. Its nests are parasitized by the neon cuckoo bee Thyreus nitidulus.[2] Human activity, for example the clearing of river banks in the Caboolture River, may threaten nest sites of this bee.

Title: Northern blue-tongued skink Description: Northern blue-tongued skink (Tiliqua scincoides intermedia) have been hit extremely hard since the arrival of Cane Toads into the Top End, and are rarely seen in urban areas anymore. I'm sure cats, dogs and habitat destruction don't help either. This is the first one I've seen in 3 years, and the second one in maybe 20 years. Seemed like a big and healthy individual, especially for one living in an area absolutely chock a block full of Carpet Pythons, cats, dogs and the occasional dingo, in an island of green near the swankier (I use the term loosely) suburbs of Darwin.

Title: Cane Toad
Description: The cane toad has poison glands, and the tadpoles are highly toxic to most animals if ingested. Its toxic skin can kill many animals, both wild and domesticated, and cane toads are particularly dangerous to dogs. Because of its voracious appetite, the cane toad has been introduced to many regions of the Pacific and the Caribbean islands as a method of agricultural pest control. The common name of the species is derived from its use against the cane beetle (Dermolepida albohirtum), which damages sugar cane. The cane toad is now considered a pest and an invasive species in many of its introduced regions.

Title: Cane Toad

The cane toad is now considered a pest and an invasive species in many of its introduced regions.

Title: cactablastus 3
Description: this caterpillar rescued Australia from the prickly pear. the prickly pear invaded vast tracts of Australia and this moth was released. it was a success story and still is at my place where I hate using chemicals. unfortunately because of this people released animals and plants that were not so useful and have done untold damage to native flora and fauna. one such animal was the cane toad.

I noticed these today. I haven't seen them in such numbers before. they never totally eradicate the pest but if they did they would eradicate themselves as it only takes one little bit of this cactus to survive before they start quickly increasing in numbers.

Title: Not Everything in the Garden is Beautiful.
Description: Cane toads (Bufo marinus) were brought to Australia from Hawaii with the intention to control the cane beetle in sugar cane fields in north Queensland. Only 102 cane toads were brought over to be bred, and 2,400 toads were released in 1935.
 Since their release, toads have rapidly multiplied in population and now number over 200 million and have been known to spread diseases affecting local biodiversity. Unfortunately, the introduction of the toads has not only caused large environmental detriment, but there is no evidence that they have affected the cane beetles that they were introduced to prey upon. The toads have steadily expanded their range through Queensland, reaching the border with New South Wales in 1978 and the Northern Territory in 1984. The toads on the western frontier of their advance have evolved larger legs; this is thought to be related to their ability to travel farther. As a consequence of their longer legs, larger bodies, and faster movement, about 10% of the leading edge cane toads have also developed arthritis!
Cane toads are capable of poisoning predators that try to eat them and they continue to spread across Australia. There is no broadscale way to control this pest but scientists are developing a better understanding of the impacts they have on the environment and the ways in which assets, such as rare and vulnerable wildlife, can be protected."

Description: So today in QLD we get to travel 150km's from home, which sounds great until you realise most of the good stuff is 200km away :(
Luckily the Bunya mts are closer.
Pride of place here is taken by the prickly pear which in 1920 covered around 240000 square km's of Australia. In 1926 they introduced a small moth from Argentina which by 1932 had practically wiped it out. Unfortunately they were so inspired with this success that when cane beetles were reducing the sugar cane yield in 1935 someone came up with the great idea of releasing cane toads.

Title: Blue Jay Description: A Blue Jay (Cyanocitta cristata) has captured a baby Cane Toad (Rhinella marina). Baby Cane Toads that have just transformed from a tadpole are the least poisonous life stage and are most vulnerable to predators. Photographed on April 8, 2020 in Coconut Creek, Florida.

Title: Blue Banded Bee - Amegilla cingulata Description: Sleeping beauty One evening last week I went into our backyard. It was dark so I took a torch with me as I was curious to see what animals I would spot. There was not much out there apart from mozzies, moths and the odd Cane Toad. I walked along our hedge and spotted sleeping native Blue Banded Bees. I found 5 of them all hanging tightly grabbing with their mandibles on a twig. I was over the moon when I found them. I have seen the occasional blue-banded bee flying in the same spot during the afternoon but haven’t seen them sleeping there. During the daytime, it is very hard to capture the bee as they are very fast and erratic flyer. I grabbed my light stand and mounted my LED Lenser torch onto it and set up my camera on a tripod with my macro gear attached. As the bee stayed in the same position I was able to photograph it as it was sleep-hanging on the twig. Description: Amegilla cingulata, commonly known as the blue-banded bee, is an Australian native bee that occurs in many other regions. Currently, several scientific organisations are researching how the blue-banded bee benefits agriculture through its distinctive "buzz pollination". These bees are very important for the production of food and contribute to at least 30% of crops in Australia. (Text Source: Wikipedia) Large photo: www.spohr-photography.com/insects/he712d21e#he712d21e I have a small blog all about Wildlife photography and photography related topics. Interested in my latest blog, Social Media Pressure? www.spohr-photography.com/blog/2020/3/social-media-pressure My passion is wildlife photography and I hope I can bring the beauty of nature into your home and show how amazing nature is. Every single animal needs our protection as they all play an important part in our survival. There is an abundance of scientific reports telling us that the rate of extinction is happening at an alarming rate. More and more fauna and flora are going to disappear. With my wildlife photography, I hope to showcase a fraction of animals before they are gone. Only what you know, you will love and protect… ©️ Spohr Photography 2020, all rights reserved

Title: Watcha lookin at? stop following me about.
Description: Common tree snake Dendrelaphis punctulata.
The common tree snake is highly variable in colour and is also known as green tree snake. The body is extremely slender and can be either grey, olive-green, various shades of brown, black, even blue and turquoise. It can inflate its body to show patches of bright blue skin between the body scales when disturbed. The underside is usually cream or yellow or light blue in some individuals. Common tree snakes are found in a variety of habitat types, but are usually seen in eucalypt woodland or rainforest areas. They are active during the day in trees and on the ground, feeding mostly on frogs and birds. They are non-venemous and grow to an average of 1.5m. This seemed to be a particularly thin individual. Maybe I need to give it a good feed. I wish it would eat cane toads, aphids, and ants.

Title: Floodplains Death Adder (Acanthophis hawkei)
Description: contact me on nick.volpe3@hotmail.com for usage of this image

This death adder is associated with the cracking soil floodplains of the Top End and Barkly Tableland. As the wet season rain brings out large amount of frogs and small mammals, these venomous snakes become more active and lay in ambush around vegetation. Their main prey is frogs - with the introduction of poisonous cane toads contributing to the large decline of this species in the Top End.

Cane Toads are one of several species of animals introduced to Bermuda, in hindsight, not always for the best.

Title: Fiji Cane Toad
Description: Mistakenly called the Fijian Ground Frog by most locals. The cane toad was introduced into Fiji to combat insects that infested sugarcane plantations. After considering the possible side effects, the national government of Fiji decided to release the toad in 1953, and 67 specimens were subsequently imported from Hawaii.Once the toads were established, a 1963 study concluded, as the toad's diet included both harmful and beneficial invertebrates, it was considered "economically neutral". Today, the cane toad can be found on all major islands in Fiji, although they tend to be smaller than their counterparts in other regions

Title: Ecophoto #4: Invasives Description: The UN SDG that comes to mind here is #15: Life on land, which aims to “Sustainably manage forests, combat desertification, halt and reverse land degradation, [and] halt biodiversity loss” (UN SDG site). Pictured here is a white mulberry tree (Morus alba) that has gradually become covered with English ivy (Hedera helix) over many years. While the tree and ivy are in my neighbor’s yard, an abundance of mulberries never fails to blanket the ground each spring. The problem lies in the nature of both plants, which are considered highly invasive within the state of Maryland (maipc.org) The ecological damage that invasive species bring to introduced areas includes: displacement of native species via competition, which leads to alterations throughout an ecosystem. Loss of native species affects organisms that rely on these species and has the potential to alter the biodiversity of a region as native species migrate to new regions, die off, or adapt to these new conditions. Sustainable management of forests relies on an understanding of: the organisms that inhabit a region, the interspecific and intraspecific interactions that occur, and contextual adjustments between an individual, population, or community viewpoint. In the case of the invasive plants above, it is clear that the English ivy is eventually going to choke out the mulberry tree, providing a possible solution to one invasive species. However, the amount of time needed for this to occur is unclear, how many more springs will the tree survive and spread its seeds before succumbing to the ivy? Also, the ivy itself only spreads its seeds after it reaches a certain height, meaning that both species are actively spreading seed and possibly disrupting other native areas. While my backyard is not a forest, I think the intertwining invasives provides an ideal example of the complexities that would be involved in sustainable forest management. For example, some native plant species may be driven away by invasives, but sudden removal of newly established invasive plants may harm organisms that have adjusted to rely on these new plants. Other than that, English ivy is incredibly difficult to control or eradicate once it is established, so what other solutions could be applied here? The answer can vary from region to region, but the central theme is a solution that minimizes costs while maximizing benefits. If we want to sustainably manage forests and other green spaces for future populations to enjoy we need to understand the intricacies present within these environments that may be altered by short-sighted solutions. This is vital to avoid ecological disasters such as Cane toads (Rhinella marina) in Australia, water hyacinth (Eichhornia crassipes) in Madagascar, or kudzu (Puereria montana) in the United States Sources: www.maipc.org/why-invasives/ www.un.org/sustainabledevelopment/biodiversity/

Title: Eastern Brown Snake on the Strzelecki Tk SA - Considered the second deadliest terrestrial snake in the world. A bit of further reading below from Wikipedia for those interested.
Description: The eastern brown snake appears to hunt by sight more than other snakes, and a foraging snake raises its head like a periscope every so often to survey the landscape for prey.[40] It generally finds its food sources in their refuges rather than chasing fleeing prey.[48] The adult is generally diurnal, while juveniles sometimes hunt at night.[49] The eastern brown snake rarely eats during winter, and females rarely eat while pregnant with eggs.[50] The eastern brown snake has been observed coiling around and constricting prey to immobilise and subdue it,[51] adopting a strategy of poisoning and grappling their prey.[48] Herpetologists Richard Shine and Terry Schwaner proposed that it might be resorting to constriction when attacking skinks as it might facilitate piercing the skink's thick scales with its small fangs.[52]

The eastern brown snake's diet is made up almost wholly of vertebrates, with mammals predominating—particularly the introduced house mouse. Mammals as large as feral rabbits have been eaten. Small birds, eggs, and even other snakes are also consumed.[49] Snakes in areas of natural vegetation or paddocks for stock eat a higher proportion of reptiles, while those in crop fields eat more mice.[49] Small lizards such as skinks are more commonly eaten than frogs, as eastern brown snakes generally forage in areas over 100 m (350 ft) distant from water.[53] Snakes larger than 7 cm (2.8 in) from snout to vent eat predominantly warm-blooded prey, while smaller snakes mainly eat ectothermic animals.[25] Other snakes, such as the common death adder (Acanthophis antarcticus),[54] and carpet python (Morelia spilota), have also been eaten.[55] Cannibalism has also been recorded in young snakes.[55] The bearded dragon is possibly resistant to the effects of the venom.[25] Although the eastern brown snake is susceptible to cane toad toxins, young individuals avoid eating them, which suggests they have learnt to avoid them.[56] Some evidence indicates they are immune to their own venom and that of the mulga snake (Pseudechis australis), a potential predator.[25]

Venom
The eastern brown snake is considered the second-most venomous terrestrial snake in the world, behind only the inland taipan (Oxyuranus microlepidotus) of central east Australia.[57] Responsible for more deaths from snakebite in Australia than any other species,[58] it is the most commonly encountered dangerous snake in Adelaide, and is also found in Melbourne, Canberra, Sydney, and Brisbane.[35] As a genus, brown snakes were responsible for 41% of identified snakebite victims in Australia between 2005 and 2015, and for 15 of the 19 deaths during this period.[59] Within the genus, the eastern brown snake is the species most commonly implicated.[55] It is classified as a snake of medical importance by the World Health Organization.[60][c]


Dangerous snake poster published by Museum Victoria in 1877
Clinically, the venom of the eastern brown snake causes venom-induced consumption coagulopathy; a third of cases develop serious systemic envenoming including hypotension and collapse, thrombotic microangiopathy, severe haemorrhage, and cardiac arrest.[61] Other common systemic symptoms include nausea and vomiting, diaphoresis (sweating), and abdominal pain. Acute kidney injury and seizures can also occur.[61] Onset of symptoms can be rapid, with a headache developing in 15 minutes and clotting abnormalities within 30 minutes;[58] collapse has been recorded as occurring as little as two minutes after being bitten.[61] Death is due to cardiovascular causes such as cardiac arrest or intracranial haemorrhage.[61] Often, little local reaction occurs at the site of the bite. The classical appearance is of two fangmarks around 1 cm apart.[62] Neurotoxicity is rare and generally mild, and myotoxicity (rhabdomyolysis) has not been reported.[61][63]

Title: Welcome Sight
Description: The local amphibians are in full swing producing their youngsters. Here a juvenile Green Tree Frog (ranoidea caerulea) has made it's home in my garden. However, a most unwelcome sight are the thousands of toxic feral juvenile cane toads (bufo marinus) also appearing in the local area.
